articles.title: Brazil Passes Landmark Law to Protect Children Online
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              The Brazilian Senate in Brasilia, February 1, 2021.
                    © 2021 Sergio Lima/AFP via Getty Images
          
    


  
(São Paulo) – Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva on September 17, 2025, signed the country’s first law to protect children’s rights online, Human Rights Watch said today. The law, called the ECA Digital after its Portuguese initials, is intended to update the country’s 1990 Statute of the Child and Adolescent to protect children’s rights in the digital environment. Technology companies with services likely to be used by children would be compelled to design products with young users’ best interests in mind and provide them with the highest levels of privacy and safety by default.“Brazilian children are finally getting the protections they need and deserve to learn, explore, and play safely online,” said Hye Jung Han, children’s rights and technology researcher and advocate at Human Rights Watch.The new law expands upon the protections for children provided by Brazil’s General Personal Data Protection Law, which are insufficient. Two of the ECA Digital’s strongest provisions directly respond to concerns raised in recent Human Rights Watch investigations. One provision prohibits online services from using children’s personal data in ways that “cause, facilitate, or contribute to the violation of their privacy or any other rights guaranteed to them by law … and the[ir] best interests.” In June 2024, Human Rights Watch documented that Brazilian children’s personal photos had been used to build powerful artificial intelligence tools later exploited to create abusive deepfakes of other children.Another safeguard in the law bans online services from profiling children to target them with behavioral advertising, which entails tracking a child’s online behavior to predict their characteristics and influence their behaviors and interests. This reflects recommendations in April 2023 and May 2022 Human Rights Watch investigations, which documented that children in Brazil and around the world had been secretly surveilled in their online classrooms and across the internet through invasive profiling and behavioral advertising techniques.Passage of this law reflects strong political will to protect children’s rights online, Human Rights Watch said. The law, which was first introduced by Senators Flávio Arns and Alessandro Vieira in 2022, unanimously passed the Senate in November 2024, cleared the Chamber of Deputies in August 2025 with support from all but one political party, and was then approved again by the Senate just one week later. This broad support enabled the bill’s passage into law despite fierce opposition from tech companies. Industry lobbying weakened some of the legislation’s original proposals, including the removal of a ban on “loot boxes” in video games – features that encourage children to spend money for randomized rewards – in the version of the bill that was approved by the Chamber of Deputies. In a notable last-minute reversal, the ban was reinstated in the final text approved by the Senate after strong opposition to the removal by Senator Arns, one of the bill’s co-sponsors.The ECA Digital is set to take effect in March 2026 and will be enforced by Brazil's data protection authority. Companies that do not comply could face fines up to 50 million Brazilian reais (US$9.44 million), or up to 10 percent of the revenue they earn in Brazil. They may also face a suspension or a ban, depending on the severity of the violation.How the law is enforced will determine whether Brazil will meaningfully protect children’s rights online, Human Rights Watch said. The data protection authority should meaningfully consult with children as it begins developing protections for children’s range of rights, and ensure that the agency’s enforcement of the law protects everyone’s rights. The government should also build on this momentum and continue to build strong data protections for Brazilians of all ages.“Brazil has stepped forward as the first country in Latin America to pass a dedicated law to protect children’s online privacy and safety,” Han said. “Other governments should watch, learn, and do the same.”
articles.content:
Click to expand Image The Brazilian Senate in Brasilia, February 1, 2021. © 2021 Sergio Lima/AFP via Getty Images

(São Paulo) – Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva on September 17, 2025, signed the country’s first law to protect children’s rights online, Human Rights Watch said today.

The law, called the ECA Digital after its Portuguese initials, is intended to update the country’s 1990 Statute of the Child and Adolescent to protect children’s rights in the digital environment. Technology companies with services likely to be used by children would be compelled to design products with young users’ best interests in mind and provide them with the highest levels of privacy and safety by default.

“Brazilian children are finally getting the protections they need and deserve to learn, explore, and play safely online,” said Hye Jung Han, children’s rights and technology researcher and advocate at Human Rights Watch.

The new law expands upon the protections for children provided by Brazil’s General Personal Data Protection Law, which are insufficient.

Two of the ECA Digital’s strongest provisions directly respond to concerns raised in recent Human Rights Watch investigations. One provision prohibits online services from using children’s personal data in ways that “cause, facilitate, or contribute to the violation of their privacy or any other rights guaranteed to them by law … and the[ir] best interests.” In June 2024, Human Rights Watch documented that Brazilian children’s personal photos had been used to build powerful artificial intelligence tools later exploited to create abusive deepfakes of other children.

Another safeguard in the law bans online services from profiling children to target them with behavioral advertising, which entails tracking a child’s online behavior to predict their characteristics and influence their behaviors and interests. This reflects recommendations in April 2023 and May 2022 Human Rights Watch investigations, which documented that children in Brazil and around the world had been secretly surveilled in their online classrooms and across the internet through invasive profiling and behavioral advertising techniques.

Passage of this law reflects strong political will to protect children’s rights online, Human Rights Watch said. The law, which was first introduced by Senators Flávio Arns and Alessandro Vieira in 2022, unanimously passed the Senate in November 2024, cleared the Chamber of Deputies in August 2025 with support from all but one political party, and was then approved again by the Senate just one week later.

This broad support enabled the bill’s passage into law despite fierce opposition from tech companies. Industry lobbying weakened some of the legislation’s original proposals, including the removal of a ban on “loot boxes” in video games – features that encourage children to spend money for randomized rewards – in the version of the bill that was approved by the Chamber of Deputies. In a notable last-minute reversal, the ban was reinstated in the final text approved by the Senate after strong opposition to the removal by Senator Arns, one of the bill’s co-sponsors.

The ECA Digital is set to take effect in March 2026 and will be enforced by Brazil's data protection authority. Companies that do not comply could face fines up to 50 million Brazilian reais (US$9.44 million), or up to 10 percent of the revenue they earn in Brazil. They may also face a suspension or a ban, depending on the severity of the violation.

How the law is enforced will determine whether Brazil will meaningfully protect children’s rights online, Human Rights Watch said. The data protection authority should meaningfully consult with children as it begins developing protections for children’s range of rights, and ensure that the agency’s enforcement of the law protects everyone’s rights. The government should also build on this momentum and continue to build strong data protections for Brazilians of all ages.

“Brazil has stepped forward as the first country in Latin America to pass a dedicated law to protect children’s online privacy and safety,” Han said. “Other governments should watch, learn, and do the same.”
articles.reasoning: The article reports on Brazil passing a landmark law to protect children's rights online, which has broad societal impact by safeguarding privacy and safety for children in the digital environment. The law addresses significant issues like data misuse, behavioral advertising, and online safety, reflecting strong political will and setting a precedent for other countries. It provides detailed context on the law's provisions, enforcement, and significance, making it a substantial and inspiring human rights advancement.
articles.personality_title: Brazil enacts first law to protect children’s rights online
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Brazil had a law from 1990 to protect children, but it did not cover the internet. As more children use online services, new rules were needed to keep them safe and protect their privacy.

**What happened** – On September 17, 2025, Brazilian President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva signed a new law called ECA Digital. This law updates the old rules to protect children’s rights on the internet. It requires technology companies to design their products with children’s safety and privacy as a priority. The law bans using children’s personal data in harmful ways and stops companies from tracking children to show them targeted ads. It also bans “loot boxes” in video games, which can encourage children to spend money randomly.

**Impact** – This law is the first in Latin America focused on children’s online privacy and safety. It responds to real problems found by researchers, like children’s photos being used to create harmful fake videos and secret tracking in online classrooms. The law has strong support from politicians and will fine companies that break the rules up to 50 million Brazilian reais (about 9.44 million US dollars) or 10% of their earnings in Brazil.

**What’s next step** – The law will start in March 2026 and be enforced by Brazil’s data protection authority. How well the law protects children will depend on how strictly it is enforced. The government plans to keep improving data protections for everyone in Brazil and wants to involve children in shaping these rules.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Brazil has passed a groundbreaking law to protect children’s rights and privacy online, setting an example for other countries to follow.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Brésil adopte la première loi protégeant les droits des enfants en ligne
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le Brésil disposait d’une loi de 1990 protégeant les enfants, mais elle ne couvrait pas Internet. Avec l’utilisation croissante des services en ligne par les enfants, de nouvelles règles étaient nécessaires pour assurer leur sécurité et protéger leur vie privée.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le 17 septembre 2025, le président brésilien Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva a signé une nouvelle loi appelée ECA Digital. Cette loi modernise les anciennes règles pour protéger les droits des enfants sur Internet. Elle oblige les entreprises technologiques à concevoir leurs produits en priorité pour la sécurité et la confidentialité des enfants. La loi interdit l’utilisation des données personnelles des enfants de manière nuisible et empêche les entreprises de suivre les enfants pour leur montrer des publicités ciblées. Elle interdit aussi les « loot boxes » dans les jeux vidéo, qui peuvent pousser les enfants à dépenser de l’argent au hasard.

**Impact** – Cette loi est la première en Amérique latine à se concentrer sur la vie privée et la sécurité en ligne des enfants. Elle répond à des problèmes réels découverts par des chercheurs, comme l’utilisation abusive des photos d’enfants pour créer de fausses vidéos et la surveillance secrète dans les classes en ligne. La loi bénéficie d’un fort soutien politique et prévoit des amendes pouvant atteindre 50 millions de reais brésiliens (environ 9,44 millions de dollars) ou 10 % des revenus des entreprises au Brésil.

**Prochaine étape** – La loi entrera en vigueur en mars 2026 et sera appliquée par l’autorité brésilienne de protection des données. L’efficacité de la protection des enfants dépendra de la rigueur de son application. Le gouvernement prévoit d’améliorer encore la protection des données pour tous et souhaite associer les enfants à l’élaboration de ces règles.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – Le Brésil a adopté une loi pionnière pour protéger les droits et la vie privée des enfants en ligne, donnant un exemple à suivre pour d’autres pays.
articles.personality_title_es: Brasil aprueba la primera ley para proteger los derechos de los niños en línea
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Brasil tenía una ley desde 1990 para proteger a los niños, pero no cubría Internet. A medida que más niños usan servicios en línea, se necesitaban nuevas reglas para mantenerlos seguros y proteger su privacidad.

**Qué pasó** – El 17 de septiembre de 2025, el presidente brasileño Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva firmó una nueva ley llamada ECA Digital. Esta ley actualiza las reglas antiguas para proteger los derechos de los niños en Internet. Obliga a las empresas tecnológicas a diseñar sus productos pensando en la seguridad y privacidad de los niños. La ley prohíbe usar los datos personales de los niños de manera dañina y evita que las empresas los rastreen para mostrarles anuncios personalizados. También prohíbe las “loot boxes” en videojuegos, que pueden animar a los niños a gastar dinero al azar.

**Impacto** – Esta ley es la primera en América Latina enfocada en la privacidad y seguridad en línea de los niños. Responde a problemas reales descubiertos por investigadores, como el uso abusivo de fotos de niños para crear videos falsos y la vigilancia secreta en aulas en línea. La ley tiene un fuerte apoyo político y puede multar a las empresas que incumplan hasta con 50 millones de reales brasileños (unos 9.44 millones de dólares) o el 10 % de sus ingresos en Brasil.

**Próximo paso** – La ley entrará en vigor en marzo de 2026 y será aplicada por la autoridad de protección de datos de Brasil. La protección efectiva de los niños dependerá de la aplicación estricta de la ley. El gobierno planea seguir mejorando la protección de datos para todos y quiere involucrar a los niños en la creación de estas reglas.

**Frase clave** – Brasil ha aprobado una ley pionera para proteger los derechos y la privacidad de los niños en línea, marcando un ejemplo para otros países.

articles.title: Press release - Parliament inaugurates permanent presence in Kyiv
articles.summary: Expressing Europe’s continued and unwavering support for Ukraine, European Parliament President Roberta Metsola officially opened the EP’s office in Kyiv. Source : © European Union, 2025 - EP
articles.content:
The decision to open an antenna office, co-located with the EU Delegation, in Kyiv sends a strong political signal to Ukrainian authorities and citizens, reaffirming the European Parliament’s solidarity and partnership.

Addressing the Members of the Verkhovna Rada, President Metsola underlined: “Know that the European Parliament will remain firmly at your side, every step of the way, until peace is secured, until freedom is restored, and until Ukraine takes its rightful place in our European family. This is why I am here this week, to strengthen our cooperation even further. We are opening a permanent office of the European Parliament here in Kyiv, so that we are present on the ground, working alongside you every day. This was our commitment to you, and we have kept it. We are here with you and we are here to stay. And as we also say, ‘You will never walk alone.’”

A long-standing partnership

Ukraine is one of the European Union’s closest and most trusted partners, and the European Parliament has built over the years a unique and enduring relationship with the Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine.

When President Metsola and Chairman Stefanchuk signed the renewed Memorandum of Understanding between the European Parliament and the Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine in November 2023, European Parliament leaders welcomed the strengthening of the multidimensional partnership first formalised in 2015, a crucial element in preparing Ukraine’s political institutions for EU integration. They confirmed the intention to establish a permanent European Parliament presence in Kyiv, further reinforcing ties with both the Verkhovna Rada and the Ukrainian people.

Since the onset of the Russian full-scale invasion of Ukraine in February 2022, the European Parliament has been leveraging its parliamentary diplomacy to reach out to counterparts across the world. The EP has adopted several solidarity measures to support Ukraine and strengthen cooperation with the Verkhovna Rada. After Ukraine was granted EU candidate status in June 2022, the Parliament intensified its cooperation with the Rada, focusing on capacity building and facilitating direct exchanges between parliamentary committees and their Ukrainian counterparts.

Unwavering support

Members reiterated in September 2025 their unwavering commitment to Ukraine’s independence, sovereignty, and territorial integrity and stressed that any peaceful solution must respect the will of the Ukrainian people and not be imposed by any other international actor.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant political action by the European Parliament establishing a permanent presence in Kyiv, symbolizing strong, ongoing support for Ukraine's sovereignty, democracy, and European integration. This has broad significance for Ukraine's political future and stability, representing a meaningful commitment to human rights and democratic values in a conflict-affected region.

**What happened** – In 2025, the European Parliament officially opened a permanent office in Kyiv, Ukraine’s capital. This office is located with the EU Delegation and shows a strong political commitment. European Parliament President Roberta Metsola spoke to Ukraine’s parliament, the Verkhovna Rada, promising continued support until peace and freedom are fully restored.

**Impact** – This is the first permanent European Parliament presence in Kyiv. It represents a close and lasting partnership between the EU and Ukraine. The office will help strengthen cooperation on political and democratic reforms, showing Ukraine that it is not alone during challenging times.

**What’s next step** – The office will work every day with Ukrainian lawmakers to support Ukraine’s plans to join the EU and rebuild after the conflict. This step builds on a 2015 agreement and recent efforts to deepen ties and help Ukraine prepare for EU membership.

**One-sentence takeaway** – The European Parliament’s new office in Kyiv marks a lasting commitment to stand with Ukraine as it works toward peace, democracy, and closer ties with Europe.

articles.title: Want to boost birthrates? Research says men need to do their part at home
articles.summary:
BY THE OPTIMIST DAILY EDITORIAL TEAM According to certain political movements, the solution to falling fertility rates sounds simple: women should leave the workforce and start producing more babies. But Nobel Prize-winning economist Claudia Goldin suggests the opposite may be true. Her latest research argues that the real fix lies not in rolling back women’s […]
The post Want to boost birthrates? Research says men need to do their part at home  first appeared on The Optimist Daily: Making Solutions the News.
articles.content:
BY THE OPTIMIST DAILY EDITORIAL TEAM

According to certain political movements, the solution to falling fertility rates sounds simple: women should leave the workforce and start producing more babies. But Nobel Prize-winning economist Claudia Goldin suggests the opposite may be true. Her latest research argues that the real fix lies not in rolling back women’s progress but in men stepping up at home in heterosexual relationships.

“Why have a child if it means giving up one’s future income and security and the child’s security?” Goldin asked while presenting her findings. Her analysis shows that countries where men shoulder more of the housework and child care tend to have higher birth rates.

Two groups, two outcomes

Goldin’s paper divides nations into two camps. In Denmark, France, Germany, Sweden, the UK, and the United States, fertility rates are relatively low but not bottoming out. In Greece, Italy, Japan, South Korea, Portugal, and Spain, birth rates are among the lowest in the world.

The difference? Time. In Sweden and Denmark, the gap between men’s and women’s unpaid domestic work is under an hour a day. In Japan and Italy, women spend about three more hours than men on unpaid care and housework. Unsurprisingly, many women in those countries delay parenthood or avoid it altogether. In South Korea, the global low point for fertility, rigid gender norms have fueled a movement known as 4B, where women are rejecting both marriage and motherhood.

What women want before having kids

Globally, women’s educational and professional opportunities have risen steadily. In the United States, women have been half the workforce since 2000. Yet even with more women in the labor force, fertility has not automatically recovered. Goldin argues that the deciding factor isn’t women’s independence but the reliability of their partners. “The real downside or obstacle is the need for husbands and fathers to reliably demonstrate their commitment,” she wrote.

In other words, before starting families, women want assurance that they won’t carry the entire load.

The policy backdrop

Supportive policies such as subsidized child care and paid leave certainly matter, but they don’t offer a holistic solution. Japan, for example, offers extensive fertility treatments and generous paternity leave, yet its birth rates remain among the lowest. By contrast, cultural expectations in places like Scandinavia, where men regularly share domestic duties, correlate with healthier fertility rates.

In the U.S., numbers show the gap is narrowing: in 2023, 74 percent of men reported spending time on household activities compared with 65 percent a decade earlier. But women still spent more time on housework and an extra hour on child care when children under six were in the home.

Why putting pressure on women won’t work

Calls from political figures for women to stay home and produce a “baby boom” miss the point entirely. Goldin warns that “reversing progressive change” could backfire, pushing rates even lower. After all, women who have invested in education and careers are unlikely to abandon both without real support from their partners.

A path forward

If nations want to raise fertility, the data suggests it’s not about medals of motherhood or nostalgic appeals to tradition. It’s about equity in everyday life. That means more men doing dishes, rocking babies at 3 a.m., and treating child care as a shared responsibility.

As Goldin’s research makes clear: fertility is not just a woman’s issue; it’s about partnership.
articles.source: The Optimist Daily: Making Solutions the News
articles.reasoning: The article highlights research by Nobel laureate Claudia Goldin showing that equitable sharing of domestic and childcare duties by men leads to higher birth rates, which has broad societal implications. It challenges regressive political narratives and promotes gender equality in household responsibilities, offering a hopeful, evidence-based path to addressing demographic challenges. The story is focused, detailed, and has meaningful real-world impact on family policy and gender roles.
articles.personality_title: Research shows men sharing housework helps increase birth rates
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Birth rates are falling in many countries, and some political groups suggest women should leave their jobs to have more children. Nobel Prize-winning economist Claudia Goldin studied this issue and found that the problem is more about men’s role at home than women’s work outside.

**What happened** – Goldin’s research compared countries with higher birth rates to those with very low birth rates. She found that in countries like Sweden and Denmark, where men spend almost as much time as women on housework and child care, birth rates are higher. In contrast, in countries like Japan and Italy, where women do much more housework than men, fewer children are born. Goldin says women want to be sure their partners will share the work before having kids.

**Impact** – This research shows that having more children is linked to fair sharing of home duties between men and women. It challenges ideas that women should give up their careers to increase birth rates. Instead, it points to a need for men to be more involved at home. This understanding could change how countries create policies to support families.

**What's next step** – Countries might focus on encouraging men to help more with housework and child care. Policies could promote shared parenting and support men’s involvement at home, not just focus on women’s roles. This could help balance family life and make having children easier for couples.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Birth rates rise when men and women share housework and child care equally, showing that parenting is a shared responsibility.
articles.personality_title_fr: La recherche montre que le partage des tâches ménagères par les hommes augmente la natalité
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Dans de nombreux pays, la natalité baisse, et certains groupes politiques suggèrent que les femmes quittent leur travail pour avoir plus d’enfants. L’économiste lauréate du prix Nobel Claudia Goldin a étudié ce sujet et a découvert que le problème vient surtout du rôle des hommes à la maison, pas du travail des femmes à l’extérieur.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – La recherche de Goldin a comparé des pays avec des taux de natalité élevés à ceux avec des taux très bas. Elle a constaté que dans des pays comme la Suède et le Danemark, où les hommes passent presque autant de temps que les femmes aux tâches ménagères et à la garde des enfants, la natalité est plus élevée. À l’inverse, dans des pays comme le Japon et l’Italie, où les femmes font beaucoup plus de tâches ménagères que les hommes, moins d’enfants naissent. Goldin explique que les femmes veulent être sûres que leurs partenaires partageront le travail avant d’avoir des enfants.

**Impact** – Cette recherche montre que la hausse des naissances est liée au partage équitable des tâches ménagères entre hommes et femmes. Elle remet en question l’idée que les femmes doivent abandonner leur carrière pour augmenter la natalité. Elle souligne plutôt la nécessité que les hommes s’impliquent davantage à la maison. Cette compréhension pourrait changer la façon dont les pays élaborent leurs politiques familiales.

**Prochaine étape** – Les pays pourraient encourager les hommes à aider davantage aux tâches ménagères et à la garde des enfants. Les politiques pourraient promouvoir la parentalité partagée et soutenir l’implication des hommes à la maison, au lieu de se concentrer uniquement sur le rôle des femmes. Cela pourrait équilibrer la vie familiale et faciliter la naissance d’enfants pour les couples.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La natalité augmente quand hommes et femmes partagent équitablement les tâches ménagères et la garde des enfants, montrant que la parentalité est une responsabilité commune.
articles.personality_title_es: La investigación muestra que compartir las tareas del hogar aumenta la tasa de natalidad
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En muchos países, la tasa de natalidad está bajando, y algunos grupos políticos sugieren que las mujeres deben dejar sus trabajos para tener más hijos. La economista ganadora del Premio Nobel, Claudia Goldin, estudió este tema y descubrió que el problema está más en el papel de los hombres en casa que en el trabajo de las mujeres fuera.

**Qué pasó** – La investigación de Goldin comparó países con tasas de natalidad más altas con otros donde son muy bajas. Encontró que en países como Suecia y Dinamarca, donde los hombres dedican casi tanto tiempo como las mujeres a las tareas del hogar y el cuidado de los niños, la tasa de natalidad es mayor. En cambio, en países como Japón e Italia, donde las mujeres hacen mucho más trabajo doméstico que los hombres, nacen menos niños. Goldin dice que las mujeres quieren estar seguras de que sus parejas compartirán las responsabilidades antes de tener hijos.

**Impacto** – Esta investigación muestra que tener más hijos está relacionado con compartir de manera justa las tareas del hogar entre hombres y mujeres. Desafía la idea de que las mujeres deben abandonar sus carreras para aumentar la natalidad. En cambio, señala la necesidad de que los hombres se involucren más en casa. Esto podría cambiar cómo los países crean políticas para apoyar a las familias.

**Próximo paso** – Los países podrían enfocarse en animar a los hombres a ayudar más con las tareas del hogar y el cuidado infantil. Las políticas podrían promover la crianza compartida y apoyar la participación masculina en casa, no solo enfocarse en el papel de las mujeres. Esto podría equilibrar la vida familiar y facilitar que las parejas tengan hijos.

**Conclusión en una frase** – La tasa de natalidad aumenta cuando hombres y mujeres comparten por igual las tareas del hogar y el cuidado de los niños, mostrando que la crianza es una responsabilidad compartida.

articles.title: Don't scrap care plans for children with special educational needs, say MPs
articles.summary: Concerns grow over the government's plans to reform special needs education in  England.
articles.content:
Don't scrap care plans for children with special educational needs, say MPs

5 hours ago Share Save Kate McGough Education reporter, BBC News Share Save

BBC/Kate McGough Parents protest outside Parliament this week ahead of reforms to special educational needs

Individual care plans for children with special educational needs, known as education, health and care plans (EHCPs), should not be scrapped, say MPs. The Education Select Committee report also calls for new minimum standards of support for special educational needs and disabilities (Send) in schools, and more training for teachers. The government is expected to publish plans on how to reform Send provision in England this autumn. They had previously refused to rule out getting rid of EHCPs. In response to today's report, the Department for Education says it is listening to families as it puts together plans to "transform outcomes for every child with Send".

The Education Select Committee has spent the past eight months looking into how to achieve long-term sustainability for the Send system in England, and how to improve outcomes for children and young people. In their report today they made several recommendations to the Department for Education, including: Keeping EHCPs and Send tribunals as a "backstop of accountability" for parents Establishing new statutory national minimum standards for what support schools should offer on special educational needs at all levels of need More Send training for all current and future mainstream school staff, including headteachers Investing in more state specialist schools Increasing per-pupil Send funding in line with inflation The National Audit Office said last year that the Send system in England as a whole "wasn't financially sustainable" and was not delivering better outcomes for children and young people, despite big increases in high-needs funding over the last 10 years. The number of children and young people in England with an EHCP has increased to 638,745, the highest number since they were introduced a decade ago. An EHCP is a legal document outlining the support for special educational needs that a child or young person is entitled to.

Nearly 1.3 million pupils are getting support for special educational needs in schools in England without an EHCP, but many parents value the legal rights to support that the plans set out and fight hard to get them put in place. Helen Hayes MP, who is chair of the Education Select Committee, says a "root and branch" reform of the Send system is needed and that "a genuinely inclusive, well-resourced mainstream education system" will bring costs down. "The government must develop a standardised, national framework for the support that children with Send can expect in school, long before requiring an EHCP, so that there can be confidence and clear lines of accountability." Paul Whiteman, the general secretary for school leaders' union NAHT, agreed that all teachers should be trained in how to support children with special educational needs but said the responsibility shouldn't just lie with schools. "There must be a collaborative multi-agency approach, with the onus not just on schools but on all health and child services to support children and young people with Send. "There must be a recognition that funding for Send is currently insufficient and a re-thought system will need to be fully resourced in order to work."

BBC/Kate McGough Tracy and her son Rowan, who has had an EHCP since he was five, joined a protest outside Parliament on Monday

The impact is broad, affecting hundreds of thousands of children and their families, and the article provides detailed context about the current challenges and proposed solutions.
articles.personality_title: MPs urge to keep care plans for children with special educational needs
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – In England, children with special educational needs can receive support through education, health, and care plans (EHCPs). These legal documents explain what help a child needs at school. The government is planning changes to this system, which has raised worries among parents and experts.

**What happened** – The Education Select Committee, a group of Members of Parliament (MPs), spent eight months studying how to improve support for children with special needs. They recommended that EHCPs should not be removed. Instead, they want clear national rules for how schools support these children, better training for teachers, more specialist schools, and funding that matches rising costs. The government is expected to share its plans soon.

**Impact** – This report is important because it protects legal rights that many families rely on to get help for their children. EHCPs cover over 600,000 children, and many more receive support without these plans. The committee’s recommendations aim to make sure support is fair and strong across all schools, not just for those with official plans. It also highlights the need for better cooperation between schools, health, and child services.

**What's next step** – The government will publish its plans for how to change the system this autumn. If the recommendations are followed, schools may have new national standards, more training, and increased funding. Families and schools will watch closely to see if these changes improve support for children with special needs.

**One-sentence takeaway** – MPs have called to keep legal care plans for children with special needs and to improve school support through clear rules, more training, and better funding.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les députés demandent de garder les plans de prise en charge pour les enfants ayant des besoins éducatifs particuliers
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – En Angleterre, les enfants ayant des besoins éducatifs particuliers peuvent bénéficier d’un plan appelé EHCP (plan d’éducation, de santé et de soins). Ce document légal explique le soutien dont un enfant a besoin à l’école. Le gouvernement prévoit de modifier ce système, ce qui inquiète parents et experts.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – La commission parlementaire de l’éducation a passé huit mois à étudier comment améliorer le soutien aux enfants avec des besoins particuliers. Elle recommande de ne pas supprimer les EHCP. Elle souhaite plutôt des règles nationales claires pour le soutien en école, plus de formation pour les enseignants, plus d’écoles spécialisées et un financement adapté à l’inflation. Le gouvernement doit bientôt présenter ses projets.

**Impact** – Ce rapport est important car il protège les droits légaux que beaucoup de familles utilisent pour obtenir de l’aide. Plus de 600 000 enfants ont un EHCP et beaucoup d’autres bénéficient de soutien sans ce plan. Les recommandations visent à rendre le soutien juste et solide dans toutes les écoles, pas seulement pour ceux avec un plan officiel. Elles soulignent aussi la nécessité d’une meilleure collaboration entre écoles, services de santé et services pour enfants.

**Prochaines étapes** – Le gouvernement publiera ses projets cet automne. Si les recommandations sont suivies, les écoles auront peut-être de nouvelles normes nationales, plus de formation et un meilleur financement. Les familles et les écoles suivront cela de près pour voir si le soutien aux enfants s’améliore.

**En une phrase** – Les députés demandent de garder les plans légaux pour les enfants avec besoins particuliers et d’améliorer le soutien scolaire par des règles claires, plus de formation et un meilleur financement.
articles.personality_title_es: Los diputados piden mantener los planes de atención para niños con necesidades educativas especiales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En Inglaterra, los niños con necesidades educativas especiales pueden recibir apoyo a través de planes llamados EHCP (planes de educación, salud y cuidado). Estos documentos legales explican la ayuda que necesita un niño en la escuela. El gobierno planea cambios en este sistema, lo que preocupa a padres y expertos.

**Qué pasó** – El Comité Selecto de Educación, un grupo de diputados, dedicó ocho meses a estudiar cómo mejorar el apoyo para estos niños. Recomendaron no eliminar los EHCP. En cambio, quieren reglas nacionales claras para el apoyo en las escuelas, más formación para los profesores, más escuelas especializadas y fondos que sigan el aumento de costos. El gobierno debe presentar sus planes pronto.

**Impacto** – Este informe es importante porque protege derechos legales que muchas familias usan para obtener ayuda. Más de 600,000 niños tienen un EHCP y muchos más reciben apoyo sin estos planes. Las recomendaciones buscan que el apoyo sea justo y fuerte en todas las escuelas, no solo para quienes tienen un plan oficial. También destaca la necesidad de mejor cooperación entre escuelas, salud y servicios para niños.

**Próximos pasos** – El gobierno publicará sus planes este otoño. Si se siguen las recomendaciones, las escuelas podrían tener nuevos estándares nacionales, más formación y más fondos. Las familias y escuelas estarán pendientes para ver si los cambios mejoran el apoyo para los niños.

**Resumen en una frase** – Los diputados piden mantener los planes legales para niños con necesidades especiales y mejorar el apoyo escolar con reglas claras, más formación y mejor financiación.
